utterances: The king responded with some reforms.
The king of Morocco did the same.

In Kuwait - the most interesting place in my mind in the Arab world today is Kuwait, which is a very small, very wealthy country where the citizens have everything they want virtually for free - schooling, housing, education, medical care, whatever.
Every citizen gets a guaranteed government job if they want.
And it's in Kuwait where you have thousands of people now for the last three months, four months, have been out in the street demonstrating.
Again, they're not calling for the overthrow of the regime, but they're publicly calling out the emir's name, saying we will not let you run an autocratic system and abuse power.
They want more representation, the more equitable representation of parliament, less corruption and more citizen involvement or engagement in public life.
They haven't articulated their demands very clearly, but these are - this is what they're talking about.
They just want to feel that they're not, they're not simply living in a shopping mall where they can go and buy six cell phones and have no other rights.
They have rights more than material rights, that's what they're saying.
So Kuwait is fascinating because it's wealthy, the government gives them everything, and they're still out there demonstrating for political change.
And I think these sentiments run throughout the whole region, including Saudi Arabia and other places, to some extent.
None of them are revolutionary in the monarchies, but none of the citizens of these countries either will accept total and permanent acquiescence in the existing power structure.

I know you're on your way from here back to the airport and back home, and I don't mean to send you there early, but a report today from the Bulgarian investigation into that terrible bombing, and, well, clearly that's going to be a development that's going to be - we're going to keep an eye on.
Rami Khouri, thank you very much for your time today.
Have a safe travel back to Beirut.
Thank you, Neal.
Good to be with you.
Rami Khouri, the editor-at-large for the Daily Star and the Issam Fares Center at the American University of Beirut, with us here in Studio 3A.
We'll be talking to him again on the phone.
Stay with us.
When we come back, we're going to be talking about mixed-status families.
If that's you, give us a call.
This is NPR News.
An outbreak of measles in the Pacific Northwest has again put the issue of vaccinations front and center.
Most of the people infected have been children who were not vaccinated.
Parents can choose whether or not to vaccinate their children.
And children, by and large, are bound by that decision.
Ethan Lindenberger is one such youngster.
He is now a high-school senior from Norwalk, Ohio.
His parents are opposed to vaccinations.
But when he turned 18, he decided to rethink that decision.

What mainly happened was I had grown up just listening to my mom and what she had told me and just assumed that was the case - that I wasn't vaccinated because vaccines are bad, and they cause all these bad effects.

And - but as I grew up and spoke to friends and saw how online, there was a large debate and heated argument between both sides of this issue, I saw that this was not as much of a black-and-white universal truth.
And when I started to look into it myself, it became very apparent there was a lot more evidence, you know, in defense of vaccinations - in their favor.
Was there a moment when you said to your mother and/or father, look; it's not safe not to get vaccinations?
For sure.

I remember I approached my mom with an article by the CDC and asked why, according to the CDC, vaccines don't cause autism and why mercury is not this extremely dangerous substance and poison found in vaccines that, you know, some people like herself would claim.
And her response was simply, that's what they want you to think.
And I was just blown away that, you know, the largest health organization in the entire world would be written off with a conspiracy theory-like statement like that.
And so moments like that I can recall back to, where I just thought, like, the concern with the evidence is not here.
When did you get vaccinated?
When did you start?
I had two vaccines when I was 2 years old.
My mom claims that one of those did not happen, or it happened against her will, and the only vaccine I should have gotten was a tetanus shot when I was 2.
And that was it.
Alongside that, I've never got any other vaccines - hepatitis, polio - anything.
And the vaccines I did get were hepatitis A, hepatitis B and a few other vaccines, including a tetanus shot.
And I have more this month.
How are things at home?
Strange.
When I got my vaccinations, my mom had always known I disagreed with her and figured that that was going to pass, but it didn't.

And once I actually had finally went out and got vaccinations, it caused some stress in the house where she looked at it as me getting vaccines for a gesture of rebellion and not for my own sake and for the sake of people around me.
And step through that leg loop.
And at about 2:45 this afternoon in New York City, a small aircraft crashed into a residential apartment building at 72nd Street and York Avenue in New York City.
There are reports, according to the FAA, of at least one fatality.
Earlier, flames were seen shooting out of two apartments in that building.
Now heavy smoke billowing from those apartments.
Joining us on the telephone from the scene in New York City is NPR's Robert Smith.
And Robert, what can you tell us about what's going on?
Well, first of all I'll say that there are so many emergency vehicles here and people on cell phones that it's very dicey service, and I apologize if I cut out here.
But just a few minutes ago, the smoke stopped coming out of the building.

Once again, this is a 50 storey residential building right on the East River, 72nd and York, a very expensive apartment building here, and this impact from a fixed-wing aircraft was around the 40th floor, counting up.
Well, just a few moments ago, the smoke stopped from there.
It looked like there were jets of water coming out.
The firefighters have successfully made it to that floor and at least mostly extinguished the fire.
We're seeing still the blackened smoke over four or five stories of the building, but the actual billowing smoke has ended.

I talked to people who actually were here for the crash and say that, you know, it was a huge fireball that came out of it, and of course, they had this sort of sickening feeling that this should happen again in New York City.
Obviously, memories are stirred by that.
As of yet, no indication from the U.S.
government or from officials in New York City that any element of terrorism was involved.

No, and you know, in fact, although there's a massive, massive police presence here, which you would see in a terrorism event, and in fact the police would be in charge in many terrorism events, it still looks like this is the Fire Department's show, meaning that they haven't sort of evacuated the greater area in the kind of thing you might see in a terrorism event.
Of course, we do now know, but so far this looks like it's a Fire Department and a fire issue.

I'm standing here by the bank of ambulances and I haven't seen anyone taken out of the building sick - I'm sorry, injured or dead, and I haven't seen any ambulance gone away yet, but it doesn't mean that there aren't still casualties up there.
Clearly, somebody was flying the plane and almost certainly had to have been injured, if not killed.
And again, the FAA does report one fatality - not known whether there were other passengers on the plane.
And Robert Smith, let me ask you.
As you look at the scene around there, obviously not New York City nor any other city in the world has fire ladders that go up that high.
So clearly the firefighters had to come up inside the building and attack it from the inside.
Yeah.
I mean, that's clearly what happened.
And like I said, we saw clearly something that looked like chutes of water coming out.
And this is what they train for.
I mean, this is a city where the fundamental part of their training is going up 40 flights up stairs with hoses and hauling those things up.
It's the kind of thing that they, you know, obviously they thought about trying to do in 9/11.
Of course, those plane impacts were too high to use hoses on.
But this one, like I said, is around the 40th floor, which is very doable here.
And this area of Manhattan, the Upper East Side, very prosperous area?
Yes.
I was talking to a woman who lives two blocks away, and she's one of the ones that at least saw the fireball afterwards.
And she lives in a very expensive apartment building, but she says nowhere near as rich as the people who live in this apartment building, who have a view of Queens and the East River.
And it's a relatively new building, in the last 20 years, so yeah, it's a nice one.
Robert Smith, thank you very much for being with us, appreciate your time.
You're welcome.
NPR's Robert Smith talking to us from the scene of an aircraft disaster in New York City.
A small plane flew into a residential apartment building at 72nd Street and York Avenue.
The FAA says there is one fatality.
Other than that, we have no information on injuries or deaths.
Stay tuned to NPR News throughout the day for the latest on this terrible incident in New York City.
I'm Neal Conan, this is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
From the studios of NPR West.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, new polls on the presidential candidates.
One shows a big shift for the Democrats, we'll have more in a moment.
First, Federal Reserve Chair Ben Bernanke is on Capitol Hill again today, talking about the plan for a bailout on Wall Street.
And here's a sense of what he's saying.

The intensification of financial stress in recent weeks, which will make lenders still more cautious about extending credit to households and business, could prove a significant further drag on growth.
Pass that plan, he's saying.
Also talking to Congress, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson, and President Bush issued a statement saying the administration will work with lawmakers to agree on a robust plan to handle the crisis.
The White House says the president may ask for TV time for a speech to the nation.
Not everyone is thrilled with this plan.
Andrew Ross Sorkin is a columnist for The New York Times, and he joins us now.
And Andrew, you had a column yesterday in The New York Times where you were sharply critical of this plan.
What's wrong with it?
Well, if you'd indulge me, I'll read you just one little passage.
And in my mind, it's stunning.
And the passage reads the following.

Decisions by the Secretary pursuant to the authority of this Act are non-reviewable and committed to agency discretion, and may not be reviewed by any court of law or any administrative agency."" Period, end of quote.
And I think when you look at that, and you see the sort of power grab that the Treasury Department is making in this $700 billion proposal, it's somewhat astonishing because there's no oversight.
And that's not to say that this proposal's a bad one.
It's not to say that this is the wrong way to do it, in that the $700 billion and the actual mechanism that they're considering are right or wrong.
I'm not even making a judgment on that.

Well, the latest opinion polls, of which there have been six or seven this week, show that maybe 53, 54 percent of the people who say they're going to vote in the referendum on Sunday are inclined to vote no. So it seems pretty certain at the moment that the constitution will be shot down.
Has that number been fluctuating?
It has.
A few months ago when Mr. Chirac first announced the date of the referendum, there was very strong support, it seemed, for the European idea and for the constitutional treaty itself.
And that rapidly sank.

As the `no' campaign gathered more momentum, there was mass unhappiness in France and discontent about the economic situation and the unpopularity of the government and a series of moves from Brussels, which appear to jeopardize some French national interests and economic interests.
And the `no' campaign has been able to sustain that since a revolutional rebellion against what is going on in both their own government and, I think, in Brussels.
